text.title: Add a Computer to a Domain on PC
text.head: Add a Computer to a Domain on PC
text.p: This wikiHow teaches you how to add a Windows 10 computer to a domain. You can add a computer to a domain using the Control Panel or Windows Settings. After you join your computer to a local domain, you can log in to the domain at the Windows Sign In screen.
text.head: Steps

list.item: Click the Windows Start button. It's the button that has the Windows logo. By default, it can be found in the task bar in the lower-left corner. This displays the Windows Start menu.

Type and press . This displays the Control Panel in the Windows Start menu. It's the app that has an icon that resembles a computer screen with graphs. Click the Control Panel, or press the Enter key to open the Control Panel.
Click . It's the green text next to the icon that resembles a blue shield next to a planet. This opens the System and Security Settings menu.
Click . It's the green text next to an icon that resembles a computer screen. This displays system information.
Click . This is across from the computer name, domain and work group information. This displays the System Properties menu.
Click the tab. It's the first tab at the top of the System Properties menu.
Click . It's the last button in the System Properties menu.
Click . It's the first radial button at the bottom of the "Computer Name/Domain Changes". You can select a Domain or Workgroup.
Type the domain name and click . Type the name or URL of the domain you would like to join. If you are not sure what the domain name is, consult the network administrator.

Type an administrator's username and password and click . You need to have permission from a network administrator to join a domain. Type a network administrator's username and password and click Ok to join.
Click . You may see a welcome prompt, and a prompt advising you to restart your computer. Click Ok to acknowledge.
Click . This closes the System Properties window. A prompt immediately displays asking you to restart your computer.

Click . Before you log in to the domain with your computer, it must be restarted. If prompted, click Restart Now. If you are not prompted to restart your computer, use the following steps to restart.
Click the Windows Start button.
Click the icon with the circle with a line through the top.
Click Restart
Click . After your computer restarts, you can log in to your computer locally using your Windows username and password, or click Other User in the lower-left corner to log in to the domain.

Type the domain name/administrator's username. In the first bar where you would normally type your Windows username, type the domain followed by a slash (/), then followed by an administrator's username. For example, "Company/adminstrator".

Type the administrative password and press . Type an administrative password in the box below the bar with the domain and user name. Press the Enter key, or click the arrow to the side of the password bar to log in to the domain.
